channel.title: Homepage on Erwin Kuhn
channel.description: Recent content in Homepage on Erwin Kuhn

item.title: Transfering state from server to client with Blazor WASM and prerendering
item.description: I wanted to brush up my Blazor skills. I had been using the new .NET framework (sidenote: I’ll give an introduction to Blazor and the whole experience of putting it into production in a separate blog post. ) in my work with Vicat, an international cement & concrete group based in France, to develop a modelling tool for long term roadmaps towards carbon neutrality. Coding with it was a joy, but I had doubts about its overall performance.

item.title: A primer on cement & concrete from the climate lens
item.description: WIP: this article is not yet complete. I am still gathering feedback and information to finalize this guide. If you arrived here, I would be very happy to hear about your thoughts on the article. This is the first post in a series about the cement & concrete industries and their place in the climate fight. It provides a general introduction to the subject, with some surprising facts I discovered along the way.

item.title: About
item.description: TL;DR I'm incredibly passionate about climate, computer science, food & wine, climbing, technology and science fiction. Pick any topic in there and I'm happy to talk hours about it. I've worked on data markets and blockchains, been a food photographer and am now focusing on writing code for the climate. You can reach me at erwin.kuhn@protonmail.com Things I've done I'm a software builder by vocation, but being of the generalist type, I've dabbled in a variety of different areas.

item.title: Now
item.description: I’m currently working with Vicat on how to get to net-zero emissions in the cement industry. With them, I’m building N-Zero, a modelling tool to create long term roadmaps towards net-zero CO2 emissions. While the project is private, I wrote a primer on the cement & concrete industries from a climate lens here. I recently caught the deep learning bug as well. Right now, I’m working on mini-dl, an educational deep learning framework built on top of JAX, and simple-grad, an introduction going from zero to a complete auto-differentiation system, similar to what PyTorch or JAX use under the hood.
